CSCE_2024Q3_C2.label: Inflation expectations for key services have eased significantly from last quarter
CSCE_2024Q3_C2.description: Twelve months from now, by what percent do you expect prices to have changed for the following items?

CSCE_2024Q3_C4.label: Consumers’ perceptions about financial stress have improved
CSCE_2024Q3_C4.description:
Do you think you (and any family living with you) are financially better or worse off these days than you were 12 months ago?  And looking ahead, do you think you will be financially better or worse off 12 months from now than you are these days?  Compared with 12 months ago, do you think it is generally harder or easier these days for people to obtain credit or loans (including credit and retail cards, auto loans, student loans and mortgages)?  And looking ahead, do you think that 12 months from now it will generally be harder or easier for people to obtain credit or loans than it is these days?  What do you think is the percent chance that you will lose your job during the next 12 months? What do you think is the percent chance that, over the next 3 months, you will NOT be able to make one of your debt payments (that is, the minimum required payment on credit or retail cards, auto loans, student loans, mortgages or any other debt you may have)?  (Standardized values)

A positive value indicates a higher-than-average level of financial stress. Values represent standard deviations from the historical mean.

CSCE_2024Q3_C5.label: High inflation and elevated interest rates continue to constrain people’s budgets
CSCE_2024Q3_C5.description:
2023Q3 to 2024Q2: Were you financially impacted by recent Bank of Canada increases in interest rates or by recent higher inflation? Did you become better off or worse off as a result?   2024Q3: These days, are you impacted financially, either positively or negatively, by the current level of interest rates or by the current rate of inflation? Compared with 12 months ago, are you better off or worse off as a result? (Share of respondents)

Note: Survey questions were changed in 2024Q3 to better reflect current inflationary and monetary policy environments.

CSCE_2024Q3_C8.label: Some consumers need much lower interest rates to trigger home-buying plans
CSCE_2024Q3_C8.description:
For respondents not planning to buy a house: If interest rates decline from their current levels, would you plan to purchase a home over the next 12 months?  You are not planning to buy a house unless rates decrease. By how much would interest rates have to decline for you to purchase a home over the next 12 months? (Share of respondents)

Note: bps means basis points.

CSCE_2024Q3_C7.label: Home-buying intentions are unchanged at historical levels
CSCE_2024Q3_C7.description: What do you think is the percent chance that over the next 12 months you will move to a different primary residence?  What do you think is the percent chance that over the next 12 months you will put your primary residence on the market for sale? Are you planning to buy or thinking of buying a house or condo now?  Renters: Are you planning to buy a house or condo during the next 12 months?  (Share of respondents)

CSCE_2024Q3_C9.label: Indicators of job prospects are moving closer to survey averages
CSCE_2024Q3_C9.description: Please think ahead to 12 months from now. By what percent do you expect your earnings to have increased (decreased)?  What do you think is the percent chance that you will leave your job voluntarily during the next 12 months? Suppose you were to lose your job this month. What do you think is the percent chance that within the following 3 months, you will find a job that you will accept, considering the pay and type of work?  What do you think is the percent chance that you will lose your job during the next 12 months? You have answered that you are looking for a job. How long have you been looking for a job? (Standardized values)

CSCE_2024Q3_C3.label: The share of consumers expecting inflation to be in the target range has continued to increase
CSCE_2024Q3_C3.description: What do you expect the rate of inflation (deflation) to be over the next 12 months? (Share of respondents)

CSCE_2024Q3_C6.label: Most consumers plan to continue reducing their spending
CSCE_2024Q3_C6.description:
Which, if any, of the following actions are you taking or planning to take in light of your expectations for interest rates? Which, if any, of the following actions are you taking or planning to take in light of your expectations for inflation? (Share of respondents who said they are reducing spending and saving more, or postponing major purchases)

The question on actions in response to interest rate expectations was not asked in 2021Q1. The question on actions in response to inflation expectations was not asked between 2021Q1 and 2022Q1.

BOS_2024Q3_C1.label: Chart 1: Widespread softness is keeping the BOS indicator negative
BOS_2024Q3_C1.description:
Contributions to BOS indicator (standardized units)

Note: The BOS indicator is a summary measure of the main Business Outlook Survey (BOS) questions. Business activity indicators are those related to past sales declines, future sales growth, indicators of future sales, employment and investment. Price and cost indicators are those related to input and output price growth as well as credit conditions. Capacity indicators are those related to labour shortages, labour shortage intensity and the ability to meet demand.

Source: Business Outlook Survey

BOS_2024Q3_C2.label: Chart 2: Business sentiment remains subdued
BOS_2024Q3_C2.description:
Excluding normal seasonal patterns, how would you rate current business conditions for your firm? (3-month moving average, double-weighted balance of opinion*)

* Percentage of firms reporting positive sentiment minus the percentage reporting negative sentiment. Responses of very good business conditions and very poor business conditions are given twice the weight of responses of good business conditions and poor business conditions. The range of potential outcomes of this double-weighted balance of opinion is -200% to 200%.

Source: Business Leaders’ Pulse

BOS_2024Q3_C5.label: Chart 5: Investment and hiring intentions remain weak
BOS_2024Q3_C5.description:
Investment spending: Over the next 12 months, is your firm’s investment spending on machinery and equipment expected to be higher, lower or the same as over the past 12 months?  Number of employees: Over the next 12 months, will the number of employees (full-time equivalent) at your organization (in Canada) be higher, lower or the same?

* Percentage of firms expecting higher investment spending minus the percentage expecting lower investment spending
† Percentage of firms expecting higher employment levels minus the percentage expecting lower employment levels

Source: Business Outlook Survey

BOS_2024Q3_C6.label: Chart 6: Firms expect wage growth to moderate gradually
BOS_2024Q3_C6.description:
Wage growth: Over the next 12 months, are increases in labour costs expected to be higher, lower or about the same as over the past 12 months? Expected wage increase: What do you expect your average wage increase to be next year?

* Percentage of firms expecting higher labour cost increases minus the percentage expecting lower labour cost increases
Note: BOS is the Business Outlook Survey and BLP is the Business Leaders' Pulse. In the BLP, for the expected wage increase, firms can select from predetermined ranges, which can be open or closed. We use the midpoints of the closed ranges. We assign a value of -1% to responses in the lowest open-ended range (“There will be a reduction in the average wage”) and 9% to responses in the highest open-ended range (“The rate of increase will be 8% or higher”).
This question in the BLP is typically asked only one month in each quarter. The question was not asked in any month during the second quarter of 2022.

Sources: Business Outlook Survey and Business Leaders’ Pulse

BOS_2024Q3_C8.label: Chart 8: Firms expect inflation to be within the Bank of Canada’s target range at all horizons
BOS_2024Q3_C8.description:
BOS estimate: Over the next two years, what do you expect the annual rate of inflation to be, based on the consumer price index? BLP estimates: What do you expect the rate of annual inflation to be in about one, two and five years from now?

Note: BOS is the Business Outlook Survey and BLP is the Business Leaders’ Pulse. In the BOS, firms can select from predetermined ranges and also provide a point estimate. In a subset of cases, firms provide a range only, which can be closed or open. If the range is closed, we use the midpoint of the range. If the range is open, we use the average point estimate of other firms in that range. The value for each quarter is the trimmed mean, excluding the two highest and two lowest responses. In the BLP, firms can select from predetermined ranges, which can be open or closed. We use the midpoints of the closed ranges. We assign a value of -1% to responses in the lowest open-ended range (“deflation”) and 9% to responses in the highest open-ended range (“8% or higher”). This question was not asked in the January or March 2022 BLP.

Sources: Business Outlook Survey and Business Leaders’ Pulse

BOS_2024Q3_C4.label: Chart 4: Few firms report labour challenges
BOS_2024Q3_C4.description:
Does your organization face shortages of labour that restrict your ability to meet demand? (Share of firms that responded yes) What would be the most important obstacles/bottlenecks to being able to meet demand? (Share of firms that selected inability to find labour)

Source: Business Outlook Survey

MPR_2024M10_F1.label: Inflation in many CPI components is running below historical averages
MPR_2024M10_F1.description:
The heatmap shows the distance of each CPI component’s year-over-year inflation rate from its historical average. The colour is white when a component’s inflation rate is close to its average and is a varying shade of red (blue) when the rate is above (below) the average. Because the historical range of inflation varies widely across CPI components, each inflation rate plotted in the heatmap is standardized by subtracting its mean and dividing by its standard deviation. This standardization is conducted using data from 1996–2019, except for Regulation-affected services and Other services, where available data begin in 2004 and 2008, respectively. Note that Regulation-affected services includes prices that are affected by government regulations either directly (e.g., child care services) or indirectly (e.g., telephone services). Values in parentheses are CPI weights (in percent). Due to rounding, weights within categories may not sum to their respective totals.

Statistics Canada and Bank of Canada calculations

MPR_2024M10_INVEST.label: Business investment and sentiment remain weak
MPR_2024M10_INVEST.description:
Quarterly data

Note: Data on sentiment are from the Business Leaders’ Pulse (BLP). Business sentiment reflects the percentage of businesses reporting positive sentiment minus the percentage reporting negative sentiment. Responses of very good business conditions and very poor business conditions are given twice the weight of responses of good business conditions and poor business conditions. The range of potential outcomes of this double-weighted balance of opinions is -200% to 200%. BLP data is presented as a quarterly average and not monthly observations.

Sources: Statistics Canada and Bank of Canada calculations and estimates

MPR_2024M10_FSI.description:

MPR_2024M10_LS.label: Few businesses are reporting labour challenges
MPR_2024M10_LS.description:
Percentage of respondents, Business Outlook Survey (BOS), quarterly data

Note: The percentage of respondents to the BOS reporting that their ability to meet demand is restricted by labour shortages and the percentage reporting that the inability to find suitable labour is the most important obstacle to meet demand.

Source: Bank of Canada

MPR_2024M10_LF_EMP.label: Labour force growth continues to outpace employment growth
MPR_2024M10_LF_EMP.description:
3-month moving average annualized growth, monthly data

Data on sentiment are from the Business Leaders’ Pulse (BLP). Business sentiment reflects the percentage of businesses reporting positive sentiment minus the percentage reporting negative sentiment. Responses of very good business conditions and very poor business conditions are given twice the weight of responses of good business conditions and poor business conditions. The range of potential outcomes of this double-weighted balance of opinions is -200% to 200%. BLP data are presented as a quarterly average and not monthly observations.

Sources: Statistics Canada and Bank of Canada calculations

MPR_2024M10_INFL_EXP_A.label: Most measures of near-term inflation expectations have continued to fall - a. Businesses
MPR_2024M10_INFL_EXP_A.description:
Quarterly and monthly data

Note: CSCE is the Canadian Survey of Consumer Expectations; BOS is the Business Outlook Survey; BLP is the Business Leaders’ Pulse. Consensus Economics’ forecasts for the next year (based on monthly data) and the next two years (based on a combination of monthly and quarterly data releases) are transformed into fixed-horizon forecasts by the weighted average of fixed-date forecasts. 1-year-ahead refers to inflation expectations for the next 12 months. 2-year-ahead refers to inflation expectations for the period 13 to 24 months from now. 5-year-ahead refers to inflation expectations for the period 48 to 60 months from now. This question was not asked in the January or March 2022 BLP.

MPR_2024M10_INFL_EXP_B.label: Most measures of near-term inflation expectations have continued to fall - b. Consumers and professional forecasters
MPR_2024M10_INFL_EXP_B.description:
Quarterly and monthly data

Note: CSCE is the Canadian Survey of Consumer Expectations; BOS is the Business Outlook Survey; BLP is the Business Leaders’ Pulse. Consensus Economics’ forecasts for the next year (based on monthly data) and the next two years (based on a combination of monthly and quarterly data releases) are transformed into fixed-horizon forecasts by the weighted average of fixed-date forecasts. 1-year-ahead refers to inflation expectations for the next 12 months. 2-year-ahead refers to inflation expectations for the period 13 to 24 months from now. 5-year-ahead refers to inflation expectations for the period 48 to 60 months from now. This question was not asked in the January or March 2022 BLP.

SPEECH_GRAV20241230_C1.label: Chart 1: Historical and projected settlement balances
SPEECH_GRAV20241230_C1.description:
Note: The settlement balance forecast is highly uncertain and depends on many factors including, for example, the level of Receiver General (RG) cash balances deposited at the Bank of Canada. The forecast assumes a constant level of RG cash balances after fiscal year-end 2024–25. This could overstate settlement balances by the amount of funding that the government may need ahead of a large maturity. The forecast also does not include the value of any potential routine overnight repurchase agreement (repo) operations (or overnight reverse repo operations) conducted to reinforce the Bank’s policy target, which would increase (or decrease) the projected level of settlement balances.

Source: Bank of Canada calculations and projections

CSCE_2024Q4_C1.label: Chart 1: Improved consumer sentiment is partly due to lower levels of financial stress
CSCE_2024Q4_C1.description:
Contributions to the CSCE index of financial health (standardized units)

Note: The CSCE index of financial health is a summary measure of five Canadian Survey of Consumer Expectations (CSCE) questions. All contributions are in standardized units showing deviations from the survey average. The first four indicators are measured as a share of respondents, while the last indicator is calculated as an interpolated median. Positive values indicate higher-than-average levels of financial health.

CSCE_2024Q4_C2.label: Chart 2: As consumers feel financially better off, fewer plan to continue reducing their spending
CSCE_2024Q4_C2.description:
Which, if any, of the following actions are you taking or planning to take in light of your expectations for interest rates? Which, if any, of the following actions are you taking or planning to take in light of your expectations for inflation? (Share of respondents who said they are reducing spending and saving more, or postponing major purchases)

Note: The question on actions in response to interest rate expectations was not asked in 2021Q1. The question on actions in response to inflation expectations was not asked between 2021Q1 and 2022Q1.

CSCE_2024Q4_C3.label: Chart 3: Consumers expect their spending to increase faster than prices
CSCE_2024Q4_C3.description: By about what percent do you expect your total household spending to increase (decrease) over the next 12 months? What do you expect the rate of inflation (deflation) to be over the next 12 months? (Interpolated median)

CSCE_2024Q4_C4.label: Chart 4: Consumers plan to increase their spending
CSCE_2024Q4_C4.description:
Over the next 12 months, how do you expect the total spending of all members of your household (including you) to change in these categories? (Double-weighted balance of opinion*)

*Percentage of respondents expecting their spending to increase minus the percentage expecting their spending to decrease. Responses of decrease significantly and increase significantly are given twice the weight of responses of decrease slightly and increase slightly. The range of potential outcomes of this double-weighted balance of opinion is -200% to 200%.

CSCE_2024Q4_C6.label: Chart 6: High prices, uncertainty and housing costs continue to weigh on consumer spending
CSCE_2024Q4_C6.description: Consider the total spending of all members of your household (including you) over the next 12 months. Do you expect your spending to be negatively, positively or not really affected by economic factors or personal circumstances? (Share of respondents) If negatively impacted: Which of the following economic factors or personal circumstances do you expect will have the greatest negative impact on your spending over the next 12 months? (Share of respondents, more than one option could be selected)

CSCE_2024Q4_C5.label: Chart 5: Home-buying intentions have increased
CSCE_2024Q4_C5.description: What do you think is the percent chance that over the next 12 months you will move to a different primary residence?  What do you think is the percent chance that over the next 12 months you will put your primary residence on the market for sale? Are you planning to buy or thinking of buying a house or condominium now?  Renters: Are you planning to buy a house or condominium during the next 12 months?  (Share of respondents)

CSCE_2024Q4_C7.label: Chart 7: Consumers see the labour market as weaker than last quarter
CSCE_2024Q4_C7.description:
Contributions to the CSCE labour market index (standardized units)

*Negative values indicate a higher-than-average probability. Note: The CSCE labour market index is a summary measure of three Canadian Survey of Consumer Expectations (CSCE) questions. All contributions are in standardized units showing deviations from the survey average. The three indicators are measured as interpolated median probabilities. Positive values indicate above-average confidence in the labour market.

CSCE_2024Q4_C8.label: Chart 8: Consumer expectations for wage growth have not changed significantly since last quarter
CSCE_2024Q4_C8.description:
Please think ahead to 12 months from now. By what percent do you expect your earnings to have increased (decreased)? (Interpolated median)

Note: The industry of their main job was not asked in 2019Q4.

BOS_2024Q4_C2.label: The BOS indicator has improved but remains below average
BOS_2024Q4_C2.description:
Contributions to BOS indicator (standardized units)

Note: The BOS indicator is a summary measure of the main Business Outlook Survey (BOS) questions. Business activity indicators are those related to past sales declines, future sales growth, indicators of future sales, employment and investment. Price and cost indicators are those related to input and output price growth as well as credit conditions. Capacity indicators are those related to labour shortages, labour shortage intensity and the ability to meet demand.

Source: Business Outlook Survey

BOS_2024Q4_C1.label: Business sentiment has remained subdued throughout 2024
BOS_2024Q4_C1.description:
Excluding normal seasonal patterns, how would you rate current business conditions for your firm?  (3-month moving average, double-weighted balance of opinion*)

* Percentage of firms reporting positive sentiment minus the percentage reporting negative sentiment. Responses of very good business conditions and very poor business conditions are given twice the weight of responses of good business conditions and poor business conditions. The range of potential outcomes of this double-weighted balance of opinion is -200% to 200%.

Source: Business Leaders’ Pulse

BOS_2024Q4_C3.label: Firms see a risk of higher prices and lower activity following the US election
BOS_2024Q4_C3.description:
Do you expect the outcome of the US election to affect any components of your business? If yes, do you expect the business component to be higher or lower than your outlook before the election?

* Percentage of firms expecting the component of their business to be higher minus the percentage expecting it to be lower

Source: Business Leaders’ Pulse

BOS_2024Q4_C6.label: Most firms are not facing binding capacity constraints
BOS_2024Q4_C6.description:
Labour shortages: Does your firm face any shortages of labour that restrict your ability to meet demand? Ability to meet demand: How would you rate your firm’s current ability to meet an unexpected increase in demand or sales?

Source: Business Outlook Survey

BOS_2024Q4_C8.label: Firms continue to expect wage and cost growth to ease
BOS_2024Q4_C8.description:
Wage growth: Over the next 12 months, are increases in labour costs expected to be higher, lower or about the same as over the past 12 months? Input price growth: Over the next 12 months, are prices of products and services purchased expected to increase at a greater, lesser or the same rate as over the past 12 months? Expected wage increase: What do you expect your firm’s average wage increase to be next year?

* Percentage of firms expecting higher labour cost increases minus the percentage expecting lower labour cost increases
† Percentage of firms expecting input prices to increase at a greater rate minus the percentage expecting input prices to increase at a lesser rate

Source: Business Outlook Survey

BOS_2024Q4_C9.label: Firms expect selling price growth to stabilize
BOS_2024Q4_C9.description:
Selling price growth: Over the next 12 months, are the prices of your firm's products and services expected to increase at a greater, lesser or the same rate as over the past 12 months?

* Percentage of firms expecting selling prices to increase at a greater rate minus the percentage expecting selling prices to increase at a lesser rate

Source: Business Outlook Survey

BOS_2024Q4_C10.label: Inflation expectations are slightly higher than last quarter
BOS_2024Q4_C10.description:
BOS estimate: Over the next two years, what do you expect the annual rate of inflation to be, based on the consumer price index? BLP estimates: What do you expect the rate of annual inflation to be in about one, two and five years from now?

Note: BOS is the Business Outlook Survey and BLP is the Business Leaders’ Pulse. In the BOS, firms can select from predetermined ranges and also provide a point estimate. In a subset of cases, firms provide a range only, which can be closed or open. If the range is closed, we use the midpoint of the range. If the range is open, we use the average point estimate of other firms in that range. The value for each quarter is the trimmed mean, excluding the two highest and two lowest responses. In the BLP, firms can select from predetermined ranges, which can be open or closed. We use the midpoints of the closed ranges. We assign a value of -1% to responses in the lowest open-ended range (“deflation”) and 9% to responses in the highest open-ended range (“8% or higher”). This question was not asked in the January or March 2022 BLP.

Sources: Business Outlook Survey and Business Leaders’ Pulse

BOS_2024Q4_C1A.label: Capital expenditures and production in the oil and gas sector are projected to increase in 2025
BOS_2024Q4_C1A.description:
Planned increases in capital expenditures and production for 2024–25 (percentage change)

Note: Chart shows oil and natural gas producers with preliminary and announced plans for 2025. Firms are categorized based on the product that accounts for the largest share in their production mix.

Sources: Guidance announcements and quarterly reports from oil and gas firms and Bank of Canada calculations

BOS_2024Q4_C7.label: Hiring intentions remain soft
BOS_2024Q4_C7.description:
Number of employees: Over the next 12 months, will the number of employees (full-time equivalent) at your organization (in Canada) be significantly higher, somewhat higher, somewhat lower, significantly lower, or the same?

* Percentage of firms expecting higher employment levels minus the percentage expecting lower employment levels.
Note: Responses of significantly higher employment levels and significantly lower employment levels are given twice the weight of responses of somewhat higher employment levels and somewhat lower employment levels. The range of potential outcomes of this double-weighted balance of opinion is -200% to 200%.

Source: Business Outlook Survey

BOS_2024Q4_C5.label: Intentions to increase investment   have become more prevalent

* Percentage of firms expecting higher investment spending minus the percentage expecting lower investment spending

Source: Business Outlook Survey

MPR_2025M01_WAGES.label: Wage growth shows some signs of moderating
MPR_2025M01_WAGES.description:
Year-over-year percentage change, monthly and quarterly data

LFS is the Labour Force Survey; SEPH is the Survey of Employment, Payrolls and Hours. LFS, microdata measures wage growth using microdata from the LFS to abstract from changes in worker characteristics, extracting a quality-adjusted price for labour. For more details, see F. Bounajm, T. Devakos and G. Galassi, “Beyond the averages: Measuring underlying wage growth using Labour Force Survey microdata,” Bank of Canada Staff Analytical Note No. 2024¬-23 (October 2024). All wage series are measured as compensation per hour except for SEPH, which is measured in terms of average weekly earnings. Private sector in SEPH excludes wages from public administration, education and health.

Statistics Canada and Bank of Canada calculations

MPR_2025M01_HEATMAP.label: Inflation in many CPI components continues to run below historical averages
MPR_2025M01_HEATMAP.description:
The heatmap shows the distance of each CPI component’s year-over-year inflation rate from its historical average. The colour is white when a component’s inflation rate is close to its average and is a varying shade of red (blue) when the rate is above (below) the average. Because the historical range of inflation varies widely across CPI components, each inflation rate plotted in the heatmap is standardized by subtracting its mean and dividing by its standard deviation. This standardization is conducted using data from 1996–2019, except for Regulation-affected services and Other services, where available data begin in 2004 and 2008, respectively. Note that Regulation-affected services includes prices that are affected by government regulations either directly (e.g., child care services) or indirectly (e.g., telephone services). Values in parentheses are CPI weights (in percent). Due to rounding, weights within categories may not sum to their respective totals.
The components include the temporary GST/HST holiday (December 14, 2024, to February 15, 2025). This tax change impacts a wide range of goods and services, particularly semi-durable goods and food services.

Statistics Canada and Bank of Canada calculations

MPR_2025M01_INFL_EXP_A.label: Inflation expectations have largely returned to normal - Quarterly and monthly data
MPR_2025M01_INFL_EXP_A.description:
a. Businesses

CSCE is the Canadian Survey of Consumer Expectations; BOS is the Business Outlook Survey; BLP is the Business Leaders’ Pulse. Consensus Economics’ forecasts for the next year (based on monthly data) and the next two years (based on a combination of monthly and quarterly data releases) are transformed into fixed-horizon forecasts by the weighted average of fixed-date forecasts. 1-year-ahead refers to inflation expectations for the next 12 months. 2-year-ahead refers to inflation expectations for the period 13 to 24 months from now. 5-year-ahead refers to inflation expectations for the period 48 to 60 months from now. This question was not asked in the January or March 2022 BLP.

Consensus Economics, Bank of Canada and Bank of Canada calculations

MPR_2025M01_SLIDER.label: The Labour market remains soft
MPR_2025M01_SLIDER.description:
Selected labour market measures compared with their historical strongest/tightest and historical weakest/softest

All variables are in percent other than the vacancy-unemployment ratio. This chart presents the current value of labour market indicators when compared with their historical worst and best values. The range of benchmarks are based on estimates of trend using different methodologies: the modified Hamilton filter;  the Hodrick-Prescott filter; values of the indicator corresponding to a period when the labour input gap was closed (adjusted for demographic changes); and, for selected indicators, trend estimates produced by the Bank of Canada . Due to limitations from the short sample, the benchmark range for vacancy measures does not include the Hodrick-Prescott filter. Data for all series are from Statistics Canada’s Labour Force Survey (LFS) unless otherwise noted. BOS is the Business Outlook Survey; JVWS is the Job Vacancy and Wage Survey. For more details, see E. Ens, A. Lam, K. See and G. Galassi, “Benchmarks for assessing labour market health: 2024 update,” Staff Analytical Note No. 2024-8 (April 2024).

Statistics Canada, Bank of Canada and Bank of Canada calculations

Highly sensitive to trade refers to sectors where more than 30% of jobs depend on exports to the United States. Less sensitive to trade refers to sectors where 30% or fewer jobs depend on exports to the United States.

FSHUB_20250219_C1.label: Chart 1: Deterioration of market liquidity was disproportionate to the quantity of assets sold to  dealers during the COVID-19 crisis
FSHUB_20250219_C1.description:
Note: Client-to-dealer flows are measured as the sum of purchases and sales of Government of Canada bonds across all maturities for asset managers and other clients in the secondary market. This measure excludes transactions from banks, provinces and municipalities as well as interdealer transactions. The phases of the COVID-19 shock follow those defined in J.-S. Fontaine, H. Ford and A. Walton, “COVID-19 and bond market liquidity: alert, isolation and recovery,” Bank of Canada Staff Analytical Note No. 2020-14 (July 2020): Phase 1 indicates when dealers met rising demand for liquidity; Phase 2 indicates significantly worsened trading conditions; Phase 3 indicates a period of relative calm following several Bank interventions. GBBP is the Government of Canada Bond Purchase Program. For more information about Roll’s bid-ask proxy, see S. Gungor and J. Yang, “Has Liquidity in Canadian Bond Markets Deteriorated?” Bank of Canada Staff Analytical Note No. 2017-10 (August 2017).

Sources: Market Trade Reporting System (MTRS) 2.0 and Bank of Canada calculations

Percentage point difference in the year-over-year inflation rate compared with the January projection, quarterly data

Sources: Bank of Canada calculations, estimates and projections

Quarter-over-quarter percentage change at annual rates, quarterly data

Note: The assumptions and scenarios were finalized on April 11, 2025.

CSCE_2025Q1_C1.label: Chart 1: Consumers are more worried than last quarter about losing their job
CSCE_2025Q1_C1.description:
Contributions to the CSCE labour market index

The CSCE labour market index is a summary measure of responses to three questions in the Canadian Survey of Consumer Expectations (CSCE).  All contributions are in standardized units showing deviations from the survey average. The three questions are measured as interpolated median probabilities. Positive values indicate higher-than-  average confidence.

CSCE_2025Q1_C2.label: Chart 2: Job security concerns are more pronounced among those working in sectors that rely on exports to the United States
CSCE_2025Q1_C2.description:
Share of workers citing weaker job security in response to trade tensions

Sectors highly sensitive to trade includes agriculture and forestry, mining and oil and gas, and manufacturing sectors. These are sectors where more than 30% of jobs depend on exports to the United States. Sectors less sensitive to trade includes all other private sector industries, where 30% or fewer jobs depend on exports to the United States, and the public sector.

CSCE_2025Q1_C3.label: Chart 3: Consumers expect their financial health to worsen
CSCE_2025Q1_C3.description:
Contributions to the CSCE financial health index

The CSCE financial health index is a summary measure of responses to five questions in the Canadian Survey of Consumer Expectations (CSCE). All contributions are in standardized units showing deviations from the survey average. The first four questions are measured as a share of respondents, while the last question is calculated as an interpolated median. Positive values indicate higher-than-average levels of financial health.

CSCE_2025Q1_C4.label: Chart 4: After decreasing for several quarters, the share of consumers who plan to reduce spending has increased
CSCE_2025Q1_C4.description:
Which, if any, of the following actions are you taking or planning to take in light of your expectations for interest rates? Which, if any, of the following actions are you taking or planning to take in light of your expectations for inflation?  (Share of respondents who said they are reducing spending and saving more, or postponing major purchases)

The question on actions in response to interest rate expectations was not asked in 2021Q1. The question on actions in response to inflation expectations was not asked between 2021Q1 and 2022Q1.

CSCE_2025Q1_C5.label: Chart 5: High prices, uncertainty and housing costs continue to weigh on spending
CSCE_2025Q1_C5.description: Consider the total spending of all members of your household (including you) over the next 12 months. Do you expect your spending to be negatively, positively or not really affected by economic factors or personal circumstances? If negatively affected: Which of the following economic factors or personal circumstances do you expect will have the greatest negative impact on your spending over the next 12 months? (Share of respondents expecting their spending to be negatively affected by any factor; more than one option could be selected)

CSCE_2025Q1_C6.label: Chart 6: Job security concerns due to the trade conflict  are causing consumers to expect to reduce their discretionary spending
CSCE_2025Q1_C6.description: Over the next 12 months, how do you expect the total spending of all members of your household (including you) to change in these categories?  (Share of respondents who said they are expecting to reduce spending over the next 12 months)

CSCE_2025Q1_C7.label: Chart 7: More than half of consumers plan to buy Canadian rather than US goods because of the trade conflict
CSCE_2025Q1_C7.description: Right now, are you changing your spending plans in response to the potential state of trade relations between Canada and the United States or because of US tariffs on Canadian goods and Canadian retaliatory tariffs? (Share of respondents)

CSCE_2025Q1_C8.label: Chart 8: Consumers expect their cost of living to increase due to the trade conflict
CSCE_2025Q1_C8.description: How do you think your cost of living would be affected if trade relations between Canada and the United States were to change relative to before the US election or because of US tariffs on Canadian goods and Canadian retaliatory tariffs?  (Share of respondents)

CSCE_2025Q1_C10.label: Chart 10: Consumers think tariffs and the Can$/US$ exchange rate are the key impediments to the Bank of Canada’s   ability to control inflation
CSCE_2025Q1_C10.description: What is the most important factor affecting the Bank of Canada’s ability to control inflation in Canada? Choose one.  (Share of respondents)

CSCE_2025Q1_C9.label: Chart 9: Consumers’ short-term inflation expectations increased markedly
CSCE_2025Q1_C9.description: Inflation expectations for each horizon: What do you expect the rate of inflation (deflation) to be?  Perceptions about current inflation: What do you think the rate of inflation (deflation) was over the last 12 months? (Interpolated median)

BOS_2025Q1_C1.label: Chart 1: The BOS indicator has declined, mainly due to weaker outlooks for business activity
BOS_2025Q1_C1.description:
Contributions to BOS indicator (standardized units)

The BOS indicator is a summary measure of results from key questions in the Business Outlook Survey (BOS). Business activity indicators are those related to past sales declines, future sales growth, indicators of future sales, employment and investment. Price and cost indicators are those related to input and selling price growth as well as credit conditions. Capacity indicators are those related to labour shortages, labour shortage intensity and the ability to meet demand.

Business Outlook Survey

BOS_2025Q1_C2.label: Chart 2: Business sentiment has deteriorated sharply
BOS_2025Q1_C2.description:
Excluding normal seasonal patterns, how would you rate current business conditions for your firm?  (3-month moving average, double-weighted balance of opinion*)

* Percentage of firms reporting positive sentiment minus the percentage reporting negative sentiment. Responses of very good business conditions and very poor business conditions are given twice the weight of responses of good business conditions and poor business conditions. The range of potential outcomes of this double-weighted balance of opinion is -200% to 200%.

Business Leaders’ Pulse

BOS_2025Q1_C4.label: Chart 4: Firms expect growth in export sales to slow markedly as US tariffs loom
BOS_2025Q1_C4.description:
Past export and domestic sales growth: How have your export and domestic sales changed (in percent) over the past 12 months?  Future export and domestic sales growth: How do you expect your export and domestic sales growth to change (in percent) over the next 12 months?

* Percentage of exporting firms expecting export sales growth to increase minus the percentage expecting export sales growth to decrease
† Percentage of exporting firms expecting domestic sales growth to increase minus the percentage expecting domestic sales growth to decrease
Respondents were asked to provide four point estimates: past export sales growth, past domestic sales growth, expected future export sales growth and expected future domestic sales growth. Balances of opinion were then calculated based on the point estimates provided.

Business Leaders' Pulse

BOS_2025Q1_C3.label: Chart 3: Firms have softer sales outlooks as trade tensions stall the recent recovery
BOS_2025Q1_C3.description:
Sales growth: Over the next 12 months, is your firm’s sales volume expected to increase at a greater, lesser or the same rate as over the past 12 months? Indicators of future sales: Compared with 12 months ago, have your recent indicators of future sales (order books, advance bookings, sales inquiries, etc.) improved, deteriorated or remained the same?

* Percentage of firms expecting sales to increase at a greater rate minus the percentage expecting sales to increase at a lesser rate
† Percentage of firms reporting that indicators have improved minus the percentage reporting that indicators have deteriorated

Business Outlook Survey

BOS_2025Q1_C5.label: Chart 5: Most firms have spare capacity
BOS_2025Q1_C5.description:
Labour shortages: Does your firm face any shortages of labour that restrict your ability to meet demand? Ability to meet demand: How would you rate your firm’s current ability to meet an unexpected increase in demand or sales?

Business Outlook Survey

BOS_2025Q1_C6.label: Chart 6: Many firms are holding off on investments
BOS_2025Q1_C6.description:
Investment spending: Over the next 12 months, is your firm’s investment spending on machinery and equipment expected to be higher, lower or the same as over the past 12 months?

* Percentage of firms expecting higher investment spending minus the percentage expecting lower investment spending

Business Outlook Survey

BOS_2025Q1_C7.label: Chart 7: High uncertainty and low demand are weighing on investment
BOS_2025Q1_C7.description:
Factors affecting investment spending

Business Outlook Survey

BOS_2025Q1_C8.label: Chart 8: Fewer firms are hiring
BOS_2025Q1_C8.description:
Number of employees: Over the next 12 months, will the number of employees (full-time equivalent) at your organization (in Canada) be higher, lower or the same? (Share of firms)

Business Outlook Survey

BOS_2025Q1_C9.label: Chart 9: Wage growth expectations have eased
BOS_2025Q1_C9.description:
Wage growth: Over the next 12 months, are increases in labour costs expected to be higher, lower or about the same as over the past 12 months? Expected wage increase: What do you expect your average wage increase to be next year?

* Percentage of firms expecting higher labour cost increases minus the percentage expecting lower labour cost increases
BOS is the Business Outlook Survey and BLP is the Business Leaders’ Pulse. In the BLP, firms can select from predetermined ranges, which can be open or closed. We use the midpoints of the closed ranges. We assign a value of -1% to responses in the lowest open-ended range and 9% to responses in the highest open-ended range (“8% or higher”). This question in the BLP is typically asked only one month each quarter. The question was not asked in any month during the second quarter of 2022.

Business Outlook Survey and Business Leaders’ Pulse

BOS_2025Q1_C10.label: Chart 10: Firms no longer expect input price increases to slow
BOS_2025Q1_C10.description:
Selling price growth: Over the next 12 months, are prices of products and services sold expected to increase at a greater, lesser or the same rate as over the past 12 months? Input price growth: Over the next 12 months, are prices of products and services purchased expected to increase at a greater, lesser or the same rate as over the past 12 months?

* Percentage of firms expecting prices to increase at a greater rate minus the percentage expecting prices to increase at a lesser rate

Business Outlook Survey

BOS_2025Q1_C11.label: Chart 11: Most businesses will raise their selling prices if tariffs impact their costs
BOS_2025Q1_C11.description:
If Canada and the United States introduce tariffs, will your input prices be affected? How much of this impact from tariffs or other trade-related policies are you planning to pass through to your selling prices in the next 12 months? (Share of firms)

Business Outlook Survey

BOS_2025Q1_C12.label: Chart 12: Inflation expectations increased again this quarter
BOS_2025Q1_C12.description:
BOS estimate: Over the next two years, what do you expect the annual rate of inflation to be, based on the consumer price index? BLP estimates: What do you expect the rate of annual inflation to be in about one, two and five years from now?

BOS is the Business Outlook Survey and BLP is the Business Leaders’ Pulse. In the BOS, firms can select from predetermined ranges and also provide a point estimate. In a subset of cases, firms provide a range only, which can be closed or open. If the range is closed, we use the midpoint of the range. If the range is open, we use the average point estimate of other firms in that range. The value for each quarter is the trimmed mean, excluding the two highest and two lowest responses. In the BLP, firms can select from predetermined ranges, which can be open or closed. We use the midpoints of the closed ranges. We assign a value of -1% to responses in the lowest open-ended range (“deflation”) and 9% to responses in the highest open-ended range (“8% or higher”). This question was not asked in the January or March 2022 BLP.

Business Outlook Survey and Business Leaders’ Pulse

BOS_2025Q1_C1A.label: Chart 1-A: Tariffs would put upward pressure on prices while reducing business activity
BOS_2025Q1_C1A.description:
Areas of business already or expected to be affected by tariffs (share of firms and direction of impact)

Respondents were not specifically asked about the areas of their business that have already been or are expected to be affected by tariffs. Results shown here are based on firms’ responses throughout each survey interview.  With the exception of four firms, all respondents that were already being affected in one direction were also expecting a future impact in the same direction.

Business Outlook Survey

BOS_2025Q1_C1B.label: Chart 1-B: Expectations about the duration of possible tariffs vary widely across firms
BOS_2025Q1_C1B.description:
How long do you expect US and Canadian tariffs to be in place? (Share of firms)

Business Leaders’ Pulse

MPR_2025M04_SLIDER.label: The labour market is in modest excess supply
MPR_2025M04_SLIDER.description:
Selected labour market measures compared with their historical strongest/tightest and historical weakest/softest

Note: All variables are in percent except the vacancy-unemployment ratio. This chart presents the current value of labour market indicators compared with their historical worst and best values. The benchmark ranges are based on trend estimates using different methodologies: the modified Hamilton filter, the Hodrick-Prescott filter, values of the indicator corresponding to a period when the labour input gap was closed (adjusted for demographic changes) and—for selected indicators—trend estimates produced by the Bank of Canada. Due to limitations from the short sample period, the benchmark range for vacancy measures does not include the Hodrick-Prescott filter. Data for all series are from Statistics Canada’s Labour Force Survey (LFS) unless otherwise noted. BOS is the Business Outlook Survey, and JVWS is the Job Vacancy and Wage Survey. For more details, see E. Ens, A. Lam, K. See and G. Galassi, “Benchmarks for assessing labour market health: 2024 update,” Staff Analytical Note No. 2024-8 (April 2024).

Sources: Statistics Canada, Bank of Canada and Bank of Canada calculations

MPR_2025M04_INFL_EXP_A.label: Short-term inflation expectations have increased, Quarterly and monthly data
MPR_2025M04_INFL_EXP_A.description:
Businesses

Note: CSCE is the Canadian Survey of Consumer Expectations; BOS is the Business Outlook Survey; BLP is the Business Leaders’ Pulse. Consensus Economics’ forecasts for the next year (based on monthly data) and the next two years (based on a combination of monthly and quarterly data releases) are transformed into fixed-horizon forecasts by the weighted average of fixed-date forecasts. 1-year-ahead refers to inflation expectations for the next 12 months. 2-year-ahead refers to inflation expectations for the period 12 to 24 months from now. 5-year-ahead refers to inflation expectations for the period 48 to 60 months from now. MPR_2025M04_WAGES.label: Wage growth shows further signs of moderating
MPR_2025M04_WAGES.description:
Year-over-year percentage change, monthly and quarterly data

Note: LFS is the Labour Force Survey; SEPH is the Survey of Employment, Payrolls and Hours. LFS, microdata measures wage growth using microdata from the LFS to abstract from changes in worker characteristics, extracting a quality-adjusted price for labour. For more details, see F. Bounajm, T. Devakos and G. Galassi, “Beyond the averages: Measuring underlying wage growth using Labour Force Survey microdata,” Bank of Canada Staff Analytical Note No. 2024-23 (October 2024). All wage series are measured as compensation per hour except for SEPH, which is measured in terms of average weekly earnings. Private sector in SEPH excludes wages from public administration, education and health care and social assistance.

Sources: Statistics Canada and Bank of Canada calculations

MPR_2025M04_HEATMAP.label: Inflation in most goods prices has risen
MPR_2025M04_HEATMAP.description:
Note: The heatmap shows the distance of each CPI component’s year-over-year inflation rate from its historical average. The colour is white when a component’s inflation rate is close to its average and is a varying shade of red (blue) when the rate is above (below) the average. Because the historical range of inflation varies widely across CPI components, each inflation rate plotted in the heatmap is standardized by subtracting its mean and dividing by its standard deviation. This standardization is conducted using data from 1996–2019, except for Regulation-affected services and Other services, where available data begin in 2004 and 2008, respectively. Note that Regulation-affected services includes prices that are affected by government regulations either directly (e.g., child care services) or indirectly (e.g., telephone services). Values in parentheses are CPI weights (in percent). Due to rounding, weights within categories may not sum to their respective totals. The components include the temporary GST/HST holiday (December 14, 2024, to February 15, 2025). This tax change impacts a wide range of goods and services, particularly semi-durable goods and food services.

Sources: Statistics Canada and Bank of Canada calculations

FSS_2025_C2.label: Chart 2: Short- and medium-term risk of a shock that could impair the Canadian financial system
FSS_2025_C2.description:
Note: The risk index is a weighted average of the ranking of each response. For the index, we assign different values to each response option: not at all likely: 0 points; slightly likely: 1 point; somewhat likely: 2 points; moderately likely: 3 points; extremely likely: 4 points. The weights are the frequency of each response. After the spring 2022 survey, the Bank of Canada reduced the frequency of the survey from twice to once per year.

FSS_2025_C3.label: Chart 3: Confidence in the financial system's ability to withstand a severe shock
FSS_2025_C3.description:
Note: The confidence index is a weighted average of the ranking of each response. For the index, we assign different values to each response option: not at all confident: 0 points; not very confident: 1 point; fairly confident: 2 points; very confident: 3 points; completely confident: 4 points. The weights are the frequency of each response. There was no Financial System Survey in spring 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. After the spring 2022 survey, the Bank of Canada reduced the frequency of the survey from twice to once per year.

Source: Bank of Canada

Note: The risk index is a weighted average of the ranking of each risk category. For the index, we assign different values to each response option: 1st choice: 3 points; 2nd choice: 2 points; 3rd choice: 1 point. The weights are the frequency of each response. After the spring 2022 survey, the Bank of Canada reduced the frequency of the survey from twice to once per year.

Note: This chart presents the current value of labour market indicators when compared with their historical worst and historical best. Benchmarks are composed of the modified Hamilton filter, the Hodrick-Prescott filter, the corresponding value of the indicator during a period when the labour input gap was closed and, for selected indicators, trend estimates produced by the Bank of Canada. Due to limitations from the short sample, the benchmark range for vacancy measures does not include the Hodrick-Prescott filter. Data for all series are from Statistics Canada’s Labour Force Survey (LFS) unless otherwise noted. BOS is the Business Outlook Survey; JVWS is the Job Vacancy and Wage Survey.

BOS_2025Q2_C1.label: Chart 1: Fewer firms than last quarter expect adverse impacts from tariffs
BOS_2025Q2_C1.description:
Areas of business expected to be affected by tariffs (share of firms revising their outlook, and the direction of the revision)

Note: In the 2025Q1 survey, responses were coded as what the firm expected if tariffs were in place. Because the tariffs were hypothetical at the time, firms could envision the degree and scope, which therefore varied across the sample. In 2025Q2, actual tariffs were in place, so responses were simply coded as what each firm expected relative to a scenario without tariffs. Note that respondents were not explicitly asked specific questions about the areas of their business they expect to be affected. Results shown here are based on firms’ responses and comments firms made throughout each survey interview.

BOS_2025Q2_C1A.label: Chart 1-A: Uncertainty is weighing on financial decisions, consumer spending and business investment
BOS_2025Q2_C1A.description: a. How consumers are responding to uncertainty Right now, is the difficulty predicting the future of the economy affecting your behaviour in one of the following ways? (Share of respondents)

BOS_2025Q2_C1B.label: Chart 1-B
BOS_2025Q2_C1B.description: b. How businesses are responding to uncertainty What are you doing differently, if anything, because of the current level of uncertainty in your outlook? (Share of firms)

BOS_2025Q2_C2.label: Chart 2: Business sentiment has improved from recent lows
BOS_2025Q2_C2.description:
Excluding normal seasonal patterns, how would you rate current business conditions for your firm?  (3-month moving average, double-weighted balance of opinion*)

* Percentage of firms reporting positive sentiment minus the percentage reporting negative sentiment. Responses of very good business conditions and very poor business conditions are given twice the weight of responses of good business conditions and poor business conditions. The range of potential outcomes of this double-weighted balance of opinion is -200% to 200%.

BOS_2025Q2_C3.label: Chart 3: Firms’ indicators of future sales are weak
BOS_2025Q2_C3.description:
Indicators of future sales: Compared with 12 months ago, have your recent indicators of future sales (order books, advance bookings, sales inquiries, etc.) improved, deteriorated or remained the same?

* Percentage of firms reporting that indicators have improved minus the percentage reporting that indicators have deteriorated

BOS_2025Q2_C4.label: Chart 4: Outlooks for export sales have improved
BOS_2025Q2_C4.description:
Past export sales growth: How have your export sales changed (in percent) over the past 12 months?  Future export sales growth: How do you expect your export sales growth to change (in percent) over the next 12 months? (Balance of opinion*)

* Percentage of exporting firms expecting export sales growth to increase minus the percentage expecting export sales growth to decrease
Note: Respondents were asked to provide two point estimates: past export sales growth and expected future export sales growth. The balance of opinion was then calculated based on the point estimates provided.

BOS_2025Q2_C5.label: Chart 5: Most firms have sufficient capacity
BOS_2025Q2_C5.description: Ability to meet demand: How would you rate your firm’s current ability to meet an unexpected increase in demand or sales? Labour shortages: Does your firm face any shortages of labour that restrict your ability to meet demand?

BOS_2025Q2_C6.label: Chart 6: Investment plans are focused on maintaining existing capital
BOS_2025Q2_C6.description:
What is the primary objective for your investment spending? (2-quarter moving average, share of firms)

Note: Because respondents could select more than one option, shares total more than 100%.

BOS_2025Q2_C7.label: Chart 7: The majority of firms plan to keep employment steady
BOS_2025Q2_C7.description: Number of employees: Over the next 12 months, will the number of employees (full-time equivalent) at your organization (in Canada) be higher, lower or the same? (Share of firms)

BOS_2025Q2_C8.label: Chart 8: Wage growth expectations continue to trend lower
BOS_2025Q2_C8.description:
Expected wage increase: What do you expect your average wage increase to be next year?

Note: BOS is the Business Outlook Survey and BLP is the Business Leaders’ Pulse. In the BLP, for the expected wage increase, firms can select from predetermined ranges, which can be open or closed. We use the midpoints of the closed ranges. We assign a value of -1% to responses in the lowest open-ended range (“There will be a reduction in the average wage”) and 9% to responses in the highest open-ended range (“The rate of increase will be 8% or higher”). This question in the BLP is typically asked only one month in each quarter. The question was not asked in any month during the second quarter of 2022.

BOS_2025Q2_C9.label: Chart 9: Due to tariffs, firms now expect input price growth to accelerate
BOS_2025Q2_C9.description:
Over the next 12 months, are prices of products and services purchased expected to increase at a greater, lesser or the same rate as over the past 12 months?

* Percentage of firms expecting prices to increase at a greater rate minus the percentage expecting prices to increase at a lesser rate

BOS_2025Q2_C10.label: Chart 10: Firms expect stable growth in their selling prices
BOS_2025Q2_C10.description:
Over the next 12 months, are prices of products and services sold expected to increase at a greater, lesser or the same rate as over the past 12 months?

* Percentage of firms expecting prices to increase at a greater rate minus the percentage expecting prices to increase at a lesser rate

BOS_2025Q2_C11.label: Chart 11: Many firms are absorbing tariff costs through their margins
BOS_2025Q2_C11.description:
How is your business reacting to cost increases from trade tensions?  (Share of firms that said they are facing higher costs)

*Share is calculated using only firms that export.
Note: Because respondents could select more than one option, shares total more than 100%.

BOS_2025Q2_C12.label: Chart 12: Businesses’ short-term inflation expectations have returned to late-2024 levels
BOS_2025Q2_C12.description:
BOS estimate: Over the next two years, what do you expect the annual rate of inflation to be, based on the consumer price index? BLP estimates: What do you expect the rate of annual inflation to be in about one, two and five years from now?

Note: BOS is the Business Outlook Survey; BLP is the Business Leaders’ Pulse. In the BOS, firms can select from predetermined ranges and also provide a point estimate. In a subset of cases, firms provide a range only, which can be closed or open. If the range is closed, we use the midpoint of the range. If the range is open, we use the average point estimate of other firms in that range. The value for each quarter is the trimmed mean, excluding the two highest and two lowest responses. In the BLP, firms can select from predetermined ranges, which can be open or closed. We use the midpoints of the closed ranges. We assign a value of -1% to responses in the lowest open-ended range (“deflation”) and 9% to responses in the highest open-ended range (“8% or higher”). This question was not asked in the January or March 2022 BLP.

MPR_2025M07_LMI_HEATMAP.label: Chart 3: Most indicators point to an excess supply of labour
MPR_2025M07_LMI_HEATMAP.description:
The heatmap shows the distance of each labour market indicator from the midpoint of its benchmark range. The colour is white when the indicator is close to the midpoint of its benchmark range, a varying shade of red when the labour market is in excess demand and a varying shade of blue when the labour market is in excess supply. To make the indicators more comparable, each indicator is divided by its standard deviation. The standard deviation is calculated using data from April 2015 to 2019 for the Job-vacancies-to-unemployment ratio and 2003 to 2019 for all other indicators. The benchmark ranges are established using the methodology outlined in E. Ens, K. See and C. Luu, “Benchmarks for assessing labour market health: 2023 update,” Bank of Canada Staff Analytical Note No. 2023-07 (May 2023).

Statistics Canada, Bank of Canada and Bank of Canada calculations

MPR_2025M07_WAGES.label: Chart 5: Wage growth continued to ease
MPR_2025M07_WAGES.description:
Year-over-year percentage change, monthly and quarterly data

LFS is the Labour Force Survey; SEPH is the Survey of Employment, Payrolls and Hours. LFS, microdata, private sector measures wage growth using microdata from the LFS to abstract from changes in worker characteristics, extracting a quality-adjusted price for labour. For more details, see F. Bounajm, T. Devakos and G. Galassi, “Beyond the averages: Measuring underlying wage growth using Labour Force Survey microdata,” Bank of Canada Staff Analytical Note No. 2024-23 (October 2024). All wage series are measured as compensation per hour except for SEPH, which is measured in terms of average weekly earnings. Private sector in SEPH excludes wages from public administration, education, and health care and social assistance.

Statistics Canada and Bank of Canada calculations

MPR_2025M07_CPI_DYNAMICS.label: Chart 6: CPI inflation excluding indirect taxes has picked up since the fourth quarter of 2024
MPR_2025M07_CPI_DYNAMICS.description:
Year-over-year percentage change, monthly data

MPR_2025M07_CPI_ENERGY.label: Chart 8: Inflation in prices of goods excluding energy has picked up
MPR_2025M07_CPI_ENERGY.description:
Monthly data

Statistics Canada and Bank of Canada calculations

MPR_2025M07_CPI_HEATMAP.label: Chart 7: The composition of CPI inflation is shifting
MPR_2025M07_CPI_HEATMAP.description:
The heatmap shows the distance of each CPI component’s year-over-year inflation rate from its historical average. The colour is white when a component’s inflation rate is close to its average and is a varying shade of blue (red) when the rate is below (above) the average. Because the historical range of inflation varies widely across CPI components, each inflation rate plotted in the heatmap is standardized by subtracting its mean and dividing by its standard deviation. This standardization is conducted using data from 1996–2019, except for Regulation-affected services and Other services, where available data begin in 2004 and 2008, respectively. Note that Regulation-affected services includes prices that are affected by government regulations either directly (e.g., child care services) or indirectly (e.g., telephone services). Values in parentheses are CPI weights (in percent). Due to rounding, weights within categories may not sum to their respective totals. The components include the temporary GST/HST holiday (December 14, 2024, to February 15, 2025). This tax change impacts a wide range of goods and services, particularly semi-durable goods and food services. The components also include the removal of the consumer carbon tax (April 1, 2025).

Statistics Canada and Bank of Canada calculations

MPR_2025M07_CPI_SHELTER.label: Chart 9: Inflation in shelter services prices is slowing
MPR_2025M07_CPI_SHELTER.description:

MPR_2025M07_CPI_RANGE.label: Chart 10: Core inflation has risen since late 2024
MPR_2025M07_CPI_RANGE.description:
Year-over-year percentage change, monthly data

Core measures included are CPI-trim, CPI-median, CPIX and CPIXFET. CPI-trim excludes CPI components whose rates of change in a given month are located in the tails of the distribution of price changes. CPI-median is a measure of core inflation corresponding to the price change located at the 50th percentile. CPIX excludes eight of the most volatile components of inflation. CPIXFET excludes food and energy inflation. All measures exclude the effect of indirect taxes.

Statistics Canada and Bank of Canada calculations

MPR_2025M07_CPI_SHAREABOVEBELOW.label: Chart 11: The share of CPI components growing above 3% has risen

Consensus Economics’ forecasts for the next year (based on monthly data) and the next two years (based on a combination of monthly and quarterly data releases) are transformed into fixed-horizon forecasts by the weighted average of fixed-date forecasts. 1-year-ahead refers to inflation expectations for the next 12 months. 2-year-ahead refers to inflation expectations for the period 12 to 24 months from now. 5-year-ahead refers to inflation expectations for the period 48 to 60 months from now. This question was not asked in the January or March 2022 BLP.

CSCE_2025Q3_C1.description:
Contributions to the CSCE indicator, average of indexes

Note: Positive values indicate that consumers’ opinions are positive compared with the survey average.

CSCE_2025Q3_C2.label: Chart 2: Consumers perceive a slight improvement in their financial health
CSCE_2025Q3_C2.description:
Contributions to the CSCE financial health index

Note: Positive values indicate that consumers’ opinions are positive compared with the survey average.

CSCE_2025Q3_C3.label: Chart 3: Consumers who believe the most serious effects of trade tensions are still to come have weaker perceived financial health
CSCE_2025Q3_C3.description:
Do you think you (and any family living with you) are financially better or worse off these days than you were 12 months ago? Perceived change in financial situation by views on when trade tensions between Canada and the United States had or will have the most serious effects on the economy (double-weighted balance of opinion*)

*Percentage of respondents perceiving their financial situation is better now than 12 months ago minus the percentage perceiving their financial situation is worse now than 12 months ago. Responses of much better off and much worse off are given twice the weight of responses of somewhat better off and somewhat worse off. The range of potential outcomes of this double-weighted balance of opinion is -200% to 200%.
Note: Among respondents, 6% think the most serious effect of trade tensions on the economy was avoided, 27% think the most serious effect has already happened, and 67% think the most serious effect is still to come.

CSCE_2025Q3_C4.label: Chart 4: Spending plans have improved for consumers who feel their financial health is better or the same
CSCE_2025Q3_C4.description:
Over the next 12 months, what do you expect will happen to the total spending of all members of your household (including you)?   Real spending growth expectations by perceived change in financial situation (median growth)

Note: The share of respondents perceiving their financial situation as better than 12 months ago is about 15% in 2025Q2 and 17% in 2025Q3. The share of respondents perceiving their financial situation as about the same as 12 months ago is about 46% in 2025Q2 and 47% in 2025Q3. The share of respondents perceiving their financial situation as worse than 12 months ago is about 39% in 2025Q2 and 35% in 2025Q3.Individual shares may not add up to 100 due to rounding.

CSCE_2025Q3_C5.label: Chart 5: High prices, economic uncertainty and housing costs continue to weigh on spending
CSCE_2025Q3_C5.description: Consider the total spending of all members of your household (including you) over the next 12 months. Do you expect your spending to be negatively, positively or not affected by economic factors or personal circumstances? If negatively affected: Which of the following economic factors or personal circumstances do you expect will have the greatest negative impact on your spending over the next 12 months? (Share of respondents expecting their spending to be negatively affected by any factor; more than one option could be selected)

CSCE_2025Q3_C6.label: Chart 6: Consumers are prioritizing Canadian-made goods and vacations in Canada over US goods and vacations
CSCE_2025Q3_C6.description:
Right now, are you changing your spending plans in Canada or the United States in response to uncertainty about trade relationships or tariffs between Canada and the United States?  (Spending plans by category, share of respondents)

Note: The questions on goods made in Canada and goods made in the United States have been asked since 2025Q1. The questions on vacationing in Canada and vacationing in the United States have been asked since 2025Q2.

CSCE_2025Q3_C7.label: Chart 7: Consumers report a lower likelihood of leaving or finding a job
CSCE_2025Q3_C7.description:
Contributions to the CSCE labour market index

Note: Positive values indicate that consumers’ opinions are positive compared with the survey average.

CSCE_2025Q3_C8.label: Chart 8: The decline in job finding prospects is more pronounced among public sector workers
CSCE_2025Q3_C8.description:
Suppose you were to lose your job this month. What do you think is the percentage chance that, within the next 3 months, you will find a job that you will accept, considering the pay and type of work? (Interpolated median)

Note: The industry of their main job was not asked in 2019Q4.

CSCE_2025Q3_C9.label: Chart 9: Consumers’ expectations for short-term inflation have changed little
CSCE_2025Q3_C9.description: Inflation expectations for each horizon: What do you expect the rate of inflation (deflation) to be?  Perceptions about current inflation: What do you think the rate of inflation (deflation) was over the last 12 months? (Interpolated median)

CSCE_2025Q3_C10.label: Chart 10: Many consumers think tariffs are the main obstacle that may interfere with the Bank of Canada’s ability to control inflation
CSCE_2025Q3_C10.description: What is the most important factor affecting the Bank of Canada’s ability to control inflation in Canada? Choose one.  (Share of respondents)

BOS_2025Q3_C1.label: Chart 1: Business sentiment is gradually recovering from recent lows
BOS_2025Q3_C1.description:
Excluding normal seasonal patterns, how would you rate current business conditions for your firm? (3-month moving average, double-weighted balance of opinion*)

* Percentage of firms reporting positive sentiment minus the percentage reporting negative sentiment. Responses of very good business conditions and very poor business conditions are given twice the weight of responses of good business conditions and poor business conditions. The range of potential outcomes of this double-weighted balance of opinion is -200% to 200%.

BOS_2025Q3_C2.label: Chart 2: Ongoing, widespread softness keeps the BOS indicator negative this quarter
BOS_2025Q3_C2.description:
Contributions to BOS indicator (standardized units)

Note: The BOS indicator is a summary measure of results from key questions in the Business Outlook Survey (BOS). Business activity indicators are those related to past sales declines, future sales growth, indicators of future sales, employment and investment. Price and cost indicators are those related to input and selling price growth as well as credit conditions. Capacity indicators are those related to labour shortages, labour shortage intensity and the ability to meet demand.

BOS_2025Q3_C3.label: Chart 3: Uncertainty remains the most pressing concern for firms
BOS_2025Q3_C3.description:
In the current quarter, what are the most pressing concerns for your company? Select up to three.  (Share of all firms)

Note: This question in the Business Leaders’ Pulse is typically asked only one month in each quarter. The question was not asked in any month during the third quarter of 2022. * The taxes and regulations category was expanded in February 2025 to include duties and tariffs on international trade.

BOS_2025Q3_C4.label: Chart 4: Subdued sales outlooks continue
BOS_2025Q3_C4.description:
Sales growth: Over the next 12 months, is your firm's sales volume expected to increase at a greater, lesser or the same rate as over the past 12 months? Indicators of future sales: Compared with 12 months ago, have your recent indicators of future sales (order books, advance bookings, sales inquiries, etc.) improved, deteriorated or remained the same?

* Percentage of firms expecting sales to increase at a greater rate minus the percentage expecting sales to increase at a lesser rate 
† Percentage of firms reporting that indicators have improved minus the percentage reporting that indicators have deteriorated

BOS_2025Q3_C5.label: Chart 5: Outlooks for export sales remain soft despite few businesses facing tariffs
BOS_2025Q3_C5.description:
Indicators of future export sales: Compared with 12 months ago, have your recent indicators of future sales (order books, advance bookings, sales inquiries, etc.) to customers outside Canada improved, deteriorated or remained the same?

*Percentage of businesses reporting that indicators have improved minus the percentage reporting that indicators have deteriorated

BOS_2025Q3_C6.label: Chart 6: Firms continue to report few capacity constraints and labour shortages
BOS_2025Q3_C6.description: Ability to meet demand: How would you rate your firm's current ability to meet an unexpected increase in demand or sales? Labour shortages: Does your firm face any shortages of labour that restrict your ability to meet demand?

BOS_2025Q3_C7.label: Chart 7: Firms with weak sales outlooks are planning for lower investment
BOS_2025Q3_C7.description:
Investment spending: Over the next 12 months, is your firm's investment spending on machinery and equipment expected to be higher, lower or the same as over the past 12 months? Indicators of future sales: Compared with 12 months ago, have your recent indicators of future sales (order books, advance bookings, sales inquiries, etc.) improved, deteriorated or remained the same?

*Contributing share to the balance of opinion on investment spending
†Percentage of firms expecting higher investment spending minus the percentage expecting lower investment spending
Note: Because non-responses are excluded from the contribution bars but included in the all-firm balance of opinion, the two measures may not align exactly for every quarter.

BOS_2025Q3_C8.label: Chart 8: Most businesses do not plan to hire new employees
BOS_2025Q3_C8.description: Number of employees: Over the next 12 months, will the number of employees (full-time equivalent) at your organization (in Canada) be higher, lower or the same? (Share of firms)

BOS_2025Q3_C9.label: Chart 9: Wage growth expectations continue to trend lower
BOS_2025Q3_C9.description:
Wage growth: Over the next 12 months, are increases in labour costs expected to be higher, lower or about the same as over the past 12 months? Expected wage increase: What do you expect your average wage increase to be next year?

* Percentage of firms expecting higher labour cost increases minus the percentage expecting lower labour cost increases
Note: BOS is the Business Outlook Survey and BLP is the Business Leaders’ Pulse. In the BLP, for the expected wage increase, firms can select from predetermined ranges, which can be open or closed. We use the midpoints of the closed ranges. We assign a value of -1% to responses in the lowest open-ended range (“There will be a reduction in the average wage”) and 9% to responses in the highest open-ended range (“The rate of increase will be 8% or higher”). This question in the BLP is typically asked only one month in each quarter. The question was not asked in any month during the second quarter of 2022.

BOS_2025Q3_C10.label: Chart 10: Firms still expect input price growth to increase and selling price growth to remain stable
BOS_2025Q3_C10.description:
Selling price growth: Over the next 12 months, are prices of products and services sold expected to increase at a greater, lesser or the same rate as over the past 12 months? Input price growth: Over the next 12 months, are prices of products and services purchased expected to increase at a greater, lesser or the same rate as over the past 12 months?

* Percentage of firms expecting prices to increase at a greater rate minus the percentage expecting prices to increase at a lesser rate

BOS_2025Q3_C11.label: Chart 11:  Slightly fewer firms than last quarter have increased their selling prices because of trade tensions
BOS_2025Q3_C11.description: What changes have you recently seen in your business operations due to trade tensions? (Share of all firms)

BOS_2025Q3_C12.label: Chart 12: Firms’ short-term inflation expectations are lower than their peak reached in early 2025
BOS_2025Q3_C12.description:
BOS estimate: Over the next two years, what do you expect the annual rate of inflation to be, based on the consumer price index? BLP estimates: What do you expect the rate of annual inflation to be in about one, two and five years from now?

Note: BOS is the Business Outlook Survey; BLP is the Business Leaders’ Pulse. In the BOS, firms can select from predetermined ranges and also provide a point estimate. In a subset of cases, firms provide a range only, which can be closed or open. If the range is closed, we use the midpoint of the range. If the range is open, we use the average point estimate of other firms in that range. The value for each quarter is the trimmed mean, excluding the two highest and two lowest responses. In the BLP, firms can select from predetermined ranges, which can be open or closed. We use the midpoints of the closed ranges. We assign a value of -1% to responses in the lowest open-ended range (“deflation”) and 9% to responses in the highest open-ended range (“8% or higher”). This question was not asked in the January or March 2022 BLP.

Note: The US Trade Policy Uncertainty Index counts the monthly frequency of articles in major US newspapers that discuss trade policy uncertainty. This index was developed in D. Caldara, M. Iacoviello, P. Molligo, A. Pretipino and A. Raffo, “The Effects of Trade Policy Uncertainty,” Journal of Monetary Economics 109 (2020): 38–59. The Economic Policy Uncertainty Index counts the number of articles in a broad set of US newspapers that discuss economic policy uncertainty. These indexes are available at policyuncertainty.com. Baker et al. refers to S. R. Baker, N. Bloom and S. J. Davis, “Measuring Economic Policy Uncertainty,” Quarterly Journal of Economics 131, no. 4 (2016): 1593–1636.

Sources: PolicyUncertainty.com, Caldara et al. (2020) and Baker et al. (2016) via Haver Analytics and Bank of Canada calculations

Calculating tariff levels from other countries on the United States before 2025 is challenging due to data limitations.

MPR_2025M10_CONSUMPTION_PC.description:
Index: 2019 = 100, quarterly data
